questions.text: Treatment of choice for early mycosis fungoides is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Electron beam therapy. Early-stage mycosis fungoides, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, is typically treated with localized radiation therapy, with electron beam therapy being a preferred option. This treatment is effective for limited skin involvement, delivering focused radiation to the affected areas while minimizing damage to the surrounding healthy tissue. It is especially beneficial for early lesions and is the first-line therapy for localized skin involvement. Incorrect Responses: A. CHOP (Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, and Prednisone) is a chemotherapy regimen used for more advanced stages of mycosis fungoides, especially in systemic involvement or when the disease has progressed beyond the skin. It is not used for early-stage disease where localized treatments are more appropriate. C. 5-FU cream (5-fluorouracil) is a topical chemotherapy agent that is sometimes used for superficial skin lesions in conditions like actinic keratosis or basal cell carcinoma. However, it is not the primary treatment for early mycosis fungoides, where radiation or phototherapy is more effective. D. IV Adriamycin (Doxorubicin) is a chemotherapy drug used for more advanced or aggressive stages of mycosis fungoides, often in combination with other treatments. It is not indicated for early-stage disease, as it may cause unnecessary side effects without providing significant benefit for localized lesions.

questions.text: A person has developed erythroderma which is pruritic, with generalized lymphadenopathy.Histopathologically, atypical T lymphocytes are seen. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sezary syndrome. Sezary syndrome is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma (widespread redness of the skin), pruritus (itching), generalized lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), and the presence of atypical T lymphocytes in the blood. It is considered an aggressive form of mycosis fungoides and represents the leukemic variant of the disease. The histopathological finding of atypical T lymphocytes and the clinical presentation with generalized symptoms strongly suggest Sezary syndrome. Incorrect Responses: B. Glucagonoma syndrome is a rare endocrine disorder caused by a glucagon-producing tumor, which leads to hyperglycemia, a characteristic rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and weight loss. While it can cause skin manifestations, it does not present with erythroderma, pruritus, or atypical T lymphocytes, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case. C. Mycosis fungoides is another form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma but typically presents with localized skin involvement initially, such as patches or plaques, which may evolve into more widespread erythroderma in advanced stages. However, the presence of atypical T lymphocytes in the blood, generalized lymphadenopathy, and erythroderma are more indicative of Sezary syndrome rather than mycosis fungoides alone. D. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that can present with erythematous plaques and scales, often on the scalp, elbows, and knees. Although psoriasis can be pruritic, it does not typically present with generalized lymphadenopathy or atypical T lymphocytes. The clinical presentation here is more consistent with Sezary syndrome.

questions.text: Sezary syndrome presents with all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nodular and tumorous growth. Sezary syndrome, a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, is characterized by erythroderma (redness of the skin), lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), and the presence of atypical T lymphocytes in the blood. However, it does not typically present with nodular and tumorous growths, which are more characteristic of advanced or different forms of lymphoma, such as in mycosis fungoides at its tumorous stage. Sezary syndrome primarily manifests with skin redness and systemic involvement without nodular growths. Incorrect Responses: A. Erythroderma is a hallmark of Sezary syndrome. The skin becomes diffusely red and inflamed, which is one of the main clinical features of the disease, along with severe pruritus (itching). B. Lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes, which is also commonly seen in Sezary syndrome. The generalized lymphadenopathy is one of the key signs of the disease, occurring alongside the skin involvement. C. Atypical T lymphocytes are typically found in the blood and skin biopsy of individuals with Sezary syndrome. These cells are clonal and malignant, contributing to the diagnosis and characterization of the disease.

questions.text: Which is not a cutaneous marker of malignancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Erythema chronicum migrans. Erythema chronicum migrans is a skin condition typically associated with Lyme disease, which is caused by a bacterial infection from Borrelia species transmitted through tick bites. It presents as a characteristic circular or expanding rash, but it is not a cutaneous marker of malignancy. Unlike the other options, it is not indicative of any form of cancer or malignancy. Incorrect Responses: A. Dermatomyositis is a cutaneous and systemic autoimmune disorder often associated with malignancies, particularly internal cancers such as ovarian, lung, and gastrointestinal cancers. The characteristic skin findings of dermatomyositis, including a heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules, can be early indicators of malignancy. B. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by dark, velvety patches of skin, commonly found in areas such as the neck, armpits, and groin. It is associated with insulin resistance but can also be a cutaneous marker of malignancy, particularly in cases of internal cancers such as gastrointestinal and endocrine tumors. C. Necrolytic migratory erythema is a rash that is often seen in patients with glucagonoma syndrome, a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. It is considered a paraneoplastic cutaneous manifestation, indicating an underlying malignancy.

questions.text: Central ulcer with waxy beaded edges is seen in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Basal cell carcinoma (BCC). Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that typically presents as a nodular lesion with a central ulcer and waxy, pearly, beaded edges. These features are characteristic of BCC, which is the most common type of skin cancer. The waxy, rolled edges are a distinguishing sign, and the central ulceration occurs as the tumor grows and erodes the surrounding tissue. Incorrect Responses: A. Paget’s disease refers to a rare form of cancer that typically affects the skin of the nipple (in the case of breast Paget’s disease) or the genital area. The lesions in Paget’s disease often appear as red, scaly patches or plaques, rather than a central ulcer with beaded edges. B. Bowen’s disease is a form of squamous cell carcinoma in situ, characterized by scaly, erythematous patches or plaques, typically with well-defined borders. It does not present with the typical central ulceration and beaded edges seen in basal cell carcinoma. D. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is another common skin cancer, but it often presents as an ulcerated lesion or an irregularly shaped tumor, not with the waxy, beaded edges seen in BCC. SCC typically has a more aggressive appearance, with thicker, more irregular borders.

questions.text: Which is NOT a risk factor for progressing to malignant melanoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diameter > 3 mm. While a larger diameter can be a feature of a melanoma, it is not considered a definitive risk factor for progression to malignant melanoma on its own. Melanomas can be small (less than 3 mm in diameter) and still be highly malignant. Therefore, the diameter of a lesion is not the most critical factor in determining its risk for malignancy compared to other characteristics like shape, border, and color. Incorrect Responses: A. Asymmetry of shape is a well-established risk factor for melanoma. Melanomas often have an irregular, asymmetrical shape, unlike benign moles, which are usually symmetrical. Asymmetry in a lesion’s shape is one of the key signs to watch for in potential melanomas. B. Irregular, scalloped, or notched borders are another risk factor for melanoma. A benign mole typically has smooth, well-defined borders, whereas melanomas tend to have irregular, scalloped, or notched edges, which indicate the lesion's ability to invade surrounding tissue. C. Variegation of color refers to the presence of multiple colors within a single lesion, which is a concerning feature in the evaluation of potential melanomas. Benign moles tend to be uniform in color, while melanomas often show a mixture of different shades, such as brown, black, blue, and even red or white. This variegation increases the suspicion for malignancy.

choices.text: Moh’s microscopic surgery gives best results
Morpheiform or sclerosing BCC are more aggressive

questions.text: Which is INCORRECT of basal cell carcinoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Relatively early nodal involvement. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a type of skin cancer that rarely metastasizes to the lymph nodes or distant organs. Nodal involvement in BCC is uncommon, especially in the early stages. This characteristic distinguishes BCC from more aggressive skin cancers like squamous cell carcinoma and melanoma, which are more likely to spread to lymph nodes and other organs. Incorrect Responses: A. They appear as “translucent” or “pearly” papules is correct. BCC often presents as a pearly or translucent papule with telangiectasias (small blood vessels on the surface), making it one of the most recognizable features of this type of skin cancer. These characteristics help differentiate BCC from other types of skin lesions. B. Moh's microscopic surgery gives best results is correct. Mohs micrographic surgery is a highly effective treatment for BCC, especially in cosmetically sensitive areas or cases with aggressive histological subtypes. It involves the precise removal of cancerous tissue while preserving healthy tissue, offering the best cure rates and minimizing tissue loss. D. Morpheiform or sclerosing BCC are more aggressive is correct. Morpheiform (sclerosing) BCC is a subtype of BCC that tends to have a more infiltrative growth pattern, making it more challenging to detect and treat. This subtype is considered more aggressive than typical BCCs and requires more careful management.

questions.text: All of following are cutaneous markers of malignancy except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cutaneous Lichen planus. Lichen planus is a common inflammatory skin condition that typically presents with purple, polygonal, flat-topped papules, often on the wrists, ankles, and genital areas. While it can be associated with hepatitis C and other autoimmune disorders, it is not generally considered a cutaneous marker of malignancy. Unlike the other conditions listed, lichen planus does not have a strong association with internal malignancies. Incorrect Responses: A. Necrolytic migratory erythema is a cutaneous manifestation of glucagonoma syndrome, a rare pancreatic tumor. It presents as red, blistering, migrating plaques, usually seen in the groin, buttocks, and extremities, and is considered a paraneoplastic sign indicating an underlying malignancy. B. Annular erythema is often associated with systemic diseases, including malignancies. It can appear as ring-shaped red lesions and is sometimes seen in conditions like lupus erythematosus, which can be related to malignancy, particularly in patients with a history of malignancy or underlying systemic disease. D. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by thickened, dark, velvety skin often found in the neck, armpits, and groin. It is commonly associated with insulin resistance, obesity, and endocrine disorders, but it can also be a cutaneous marker of malignancy, especially in cases of gastrointestinal and endocrine tumors.

questions.text: Malignant transformation to melanoma is common in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Large Congenital nevus. Large congenital nevi, also known as giant congenital nevi, are significantly larger than common moles and are associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation to melanoma. These nevi have a higher likelihood of developing into melanoma over a person’s lifetime, especially if they have irregular borders, varying colors, or other concerning features. This risk is higher compared to other types of nevi, making monitoring and potential removal of these lesions important. Incorrect Responses: A. Dermal nevus is a type of benign mole that originates in the dermis. While dermal nevi can be raised and firm, they do not typically transform into melanoma. These nevi are generally considered low-risk for malignant transformation compared to congenital or junctional nevi. B. Junctional nevus is a benign mole found at the junction of the epidermis and dermis. While junctional nevi have a slightly higher risk of malignant transformation than dermal nevi, the risk is still much lower compared to large congenital nevi. They are typically stable over time, although any changing nevus should be evaluated by a dermatologist. D. Becker’s nevus is a type of pigmented lesion often seen in males, typically appearing on the upper body. Although Becker’s nevi can sometimes become more prominent with age and may contain hair follicles, they are generally not associated with a significant risk of melanoma development.

questions.text: Which oral condition is not premalignant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aphthous ulcer. Aphthous ulcers, also known as canker sores, are common, benign, and self-limiting oral lesions that do not carry a risk of malignant transformation. They are typically associated with triggers such as stress, hormonal changes, or minor trauma and heal without the need for medical intervention. Aphthous ulcers are not considered premalignant and do not predispose to oral cancer. Incorrect Responses: A. Oral submucous fibrosis is a premalignant condition that involves the fibrosis and stiffening of the oral mucosa. It is often associated with betel nut chewing or tobacco use and carries a significant risk of progression to oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). B. Erythroplakia is a red, velvety lesion that can appear on the mucosal surfaces of the mouth. It is considered a high-risk premalignant condition because it has a higher likelihood of transforming into oral cancer compared to leukoplakia. It warrants close monitoring and biopsy. C. Leukoplakia is a white, keratotic lesion found in the mouth that is also considered a premalignant condition. While it does not always progress to malignancy, there is an increased risk of malignant transformation, especially in cases with dysplasia. Regular monitoring is recommended for leukoplakia lesions.

choices.text: SCC is more common than BCC
SCC occurs in sun exposed part of body only

questions.text: What is true about squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most common in transplant recipients. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is more common in individuals who have undergone organ transplants, such as kidney, heart, or liver transplants. These patients are often on immunosuppressive therapy to prevent organ rejection, which increases the risk of developing skin cancers, including SCC. In transplant recipients, SCC can occur even in areas of the body that are not typically sun-exposed due to the suppressed immune system’s inability to effectively control abnormal cell growth. Incorrect Responses: A. SCC is more common than BCC is incorrect. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is actually the most common type of skin cancer, with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) being less common overall. While SCC is more aggressive and has a higher potential to metastasize compared to BCC, BCC is still more prevalent. B. SCC occurs in sun-exposed parts of the body only is incorrect. While SCC is more common in sun-exposed areas, it can also occur in non-sun-exposed areas, especially in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as transplant recipients or those with certain genetic conditions. D. Has a pearly rolled edge is incorrect. A pearly rolled edge is characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), not squamous cell carcinoma. SCC typically presents as an ulcerated, crusted, or raised lesion with irregular borders, rather than the smooth, pearly appearance seen in BCC.

questions.text: There is a 0.3 cm ulcerated nodule on nasolabial fold. Diagnosis is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Basal cell carcinoma can present as a shiny, skin-colored bump that's translucent, meaning you can see a bit through the surface. The bump can look pearly white or pink on white skin.It can also present as ulcerated nodule on nasolabial fold with in a burrowing in appearance known as rodent ulcer. Option B-Most melanomas are brown and black, but they can also be pink, tan, or white. Option C-Squamous cell carcinoma has everted edges. Option D-Kaposi Sarcoma presents as cancerous lesions (spots) on the skin that are purple, red or brown and can appear flat or raised.

questions.text: A 70 year old patient develop the following lesion over face since 2 years. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Basal cell carcinoma presents with nodular lesion over tha face with beaded rolled out margins. Option B-Squamous cell carcinoma can cause everted margins. Option C-Malignant melanoma can cause variegated appearance with irregular borders. Option D-keratoacanthoma is a fast-growing, dome-shaped skin tumor that usually occurs on sun-exposed areas of the body, especially the head, neck, arms, legs, and back of the hands. Keratoacanthomas often begin in a hair follicle.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a case of Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) which are benign, pigmented melanocytic nevi present at birth. They are most commonly brown, black, purplish or red, usually a palpable lesion with heterogeneous color and texture.Malignant melanoma is more commonly associated with a congenital melanocytic nevus.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient presented with the following lesions, Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Basal cell carcinoma presents with nodular lesion on sun exposed areas such as face with beaded rolled out margins. Option B-Squamous cell carcinoma presents with everted margins. Option C-Malignat melanoma shows variegated colours. Option D-Bowen's Disease is a carcinoma in situ seen on penis.
